John R. Frank wrote:

> > You might consider broadening the key to accomodate timestamp or you
> > might put your timestamp in place of the key tail ordinal of 64 bits
> > (You may want to keep some ordinal aspect in the key for when the
> > numbers of URIs gets large).
>
> What do you think of my adding a flag to the existing calculateInsertKey
> that allows timestamps to be appended to the tail of key if the operator
> chooses to take that performance hit?  A couple other things would need to
> know about the existence of these longer keys, but not too many things.

You could do that but would probably make more sense subclassing, 
especially if you're making changes in a few places.

>
> I haven't tested the impact of this kind of key change in berkdb.  Many of
> the starting points for consideration are here:
> http://www.sleepycat.com/docs/ref/am_misc/tune.html
> http://www.sleepycat.com/docs/ref/am_conf/pagesize.html
>
> I cannot find any use of pagesize in Heritrix, which means that it is
> defaulting to something that it detects about the underlying IO system
> during build.  Is this overridden by Java.  We might want to choose a
> larger pagesize to minimize seeking to new blocks.  What is the current
> Hertrix-think on this?

FYI: We use the bdb-je product John, the pure-java bdb, not 'Berkeley 
DB', so the above cited pages with their concerns for page-size are not 
directly pertinent.

But yeah, a bigger key will come at a cost.  We'd have to do some 
measurements.  I'm guessing it'd be minor in the scheme of things (We 
could ask on the bdbje list if they've done any measurements.  The've 
been really helpful in the past).

> You mentioned an Alexa "normalizer" that removed "boring" elements from
> documents before comparing them.  That would be a useful catalog to use
> for reference in building a statistical tool that gets trained to
> recognize interesting changes.  Is there any information available on the
> Alexa normalizer?

I don't think there is public information available on techniques used 
by Alexa.  Let me ask and I'll post the list if I find out otherwise.

On the resemblance of pages, there's been quite a bit written.  This 
seems to be the 'classic': 
http://citeseer.ist.psu.edu/broder97resemblance.html.

St.Ack
